text: this is Nicholas Kristof in
port-au-prince Haiti and one of the
problems here is that there is not a lot
of topsoil and not a lot of fertilizer
to produce better agriculture and
another problem is that there is cholera
and not a lot of sanitation Sasha tell
me where we are and what we're seeing so
we are standing in the middle of the
city dump here for all of port-au-prince
this area is called treat ca and prior
to the earthquake this was the site that
received all of the solid wastes in the
city they currently bring about 40,000
gallons per day of human waste into the
dumb initially they just got dumped
along the roadsides but now they
actually have a pit out at the end where
all of the wastes go in the park so this
is basically port-au-prince is sewage
treatment facility except that it's not
treatment and not a facility
thanks I would bet dollars who done that
serious
color
okay so there are hundreds of people
that come out here every day to dig
through the garbage to see if they can
find old metal bottles anything they
might be able to sell and the problem is
when you dump the sewage in the same
place that you dump the garbage you put
all of the people who are out here
searching through the garbage at great
risk especially in this time of cholera
and as we're driving out you'll see
there are still people out here digging
through the garbage the road is wet here
but it hasn't rained there is certainly
a chance that what we're looking at
right here is a sewage that's leaked out
of the trucks hmm
Sasha runs an organization called soil
tell me a little bit about your miracle
technology right behind you that can
tackle both cholera and also the problem
of lack the fertilizer okay so I'm
actually standing in the doorway to a
dry composting toilet soils been
building these toilets in Haiti since
2006 but we were mainly working in rural
areas and in the north after the
earthquake we came to port-au-prince and
began implementing this technology in
camps where people who had been
displaced by the earthquake for living
so I'll show you the way that this
toilet works what we have here is a
toilet seat that we make in
port-au-prince and the way that it works
is that it separates the urine and the
poop so the urine goes down underground
into a soakaway pit and then the poop
falls into this 15 gallon drum
right now getting about 80 of these
drums per week from our 19 pilots
so you're telling me that this right in
front of us is a big pile of human waste
this is a pile of poop right here it
sure is this has I believe about a
hundred and twenty of those drums that
we saw have been emptied into this bin
and then mixed with this sugarcane
by-product I mean you can should be able
to see there's absolutely no flies here
standing over it there's really no smell
and this is a garden that you will be
growing fertilized with local poop is
that right that is the idea yeah this is
a community urban gardening project that
they're doing here and the idea is that
in six months when we start to have
usable fertilizer from these compost
bins that came from the toilets they
will actually be able to reuse that
fertilizer right here on site so when
people use these toilets they're
actually contributing to this community
garden that will later be providing food
to the community if this were a Disney
film would be something about the circle
of life
exactly we do need a theme song
